body: Would be awesome to have a panel to see http(s) requests directly from IDE :) I didn't find any issue about this but remember reading something about this somewhere ^^ The idea would be to have something similar of what we have in the web developer tools So a list of calls with possibility to see the content in plain text (or if json in parsed format with collapse/expand), the request and the response. And why not cookies also. And if we want cherry on top of the cake I'll add the possibility to delay an http response to see how our app handle long requests, possibility to force an error, or even the possibility to edit request and response on the fly ^^

comment_data.body:
> I didn't find any issue about this but remember reading something about this somewhere

You may have seen https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/issues/2200#issuecomment-387096683 by @johnpryan but I know we've talked about it elsewhere too...

Definitely something we'd like to do. üëç

@pq is there any docs on how this plugin works? I might be interested in working on this :) but for example I don't know how retrieve http info from the app. So any info on how the dialog between plugin and the app might be good to know to work on this :)
Hey @pq is this something similar to create test and will need dart analyser update to be able to retrieve http calls data?
I don't think so.  It *may* require (or at least benefit) from Flutter framework hooks though...

Hey @pq ! So ok my idea:

It will not involve any changes on Flutter side.
Create a wrapper around IOClient, this wrapper will basically use the IDE as a proxy and send http request to the IDE plugin. Then the plugin can execute request and show data but also interact with the requests (delay, change requests/responses).

Another solution to at least quickly having http reporting is that this IOClient wrapping just log all http information in a specific format, then the plugin can extract them to just show them under `Http monitoring` tab.

The developers would have to use this IOClient wrapper to see http reporting into their IDE. It could be as easy as `final ioClient = isProductionEnv ? IOClient() : ProxyIdeIoClient()`.
What do you think ?

Ho that really nice @pq !!! You basically already have the basic http reporting ! 
So go for the final solution then, right ? I didn't know about this httpOverrides technic ! It's awesome ^^ basically we can create our own HttpClient implementation that will use IDE as proxy. 

One thing that is not clear yet on my mind is how the app and the IDE can exchange the data... If we use logs as you did then no possibility to delay or change request/response later... 

What do you think @pq ?

> One thing that is not clear yet on my mind is how the app and the IDE can exchange the data... If we use logs as you did then no possibility to delay or change request/response later...

Could you elaborate on this?  I think I know what you have in mind but if you described a scenario that'd be useful to make sure we're on the same page.

Thanks!

Sure !!! So some use cases would be: 

Playing with my app and see on http monitoring panel that one request is giving me a 400, click right on it and select "Breakpoint request", then play with the app to retry the call, IDE is intercepting the request and show me a popup with the request data, I'm changing the header `Content-type` because it was not correct and click "ok", request is done and successful this time. I'm happy and can change the code accordingly to set the correct header.

I have same case for "Breakpoint response" that will show a popup for me to edit the response before it goes to the app. 

Another case is just to "add request delay" like this I can add 1 minutes before the response is sent to the app, like this I can test the case where network is really low and see how it's handled on my app. 

Clear enough @pq  ?
I just tried your http logs with https://github.com/pq/logs ! Works great ! I personally miss the data sent/received during POST/PUT....
DevTools is getting a networking page.

milestone.description: Work triaged but not yet planned for a specific release.
milestone.title: Backlog

title: Having an Http monitoring panel
